awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Combinatorial Inverse Problems in Distance Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
From navigating the seas to reconstructing the shape of proteins, reasoning from distances is at the heart of civilization. In many applications one has a list of distances but no labeling information to assign them to objects. For example, when navigating buildings by multipath, echoes coming from different walls all look the same; when solving the geometry of nanostructured materials by powder diffraction, distances between different pairs of atoms are all summarized in a single pair distribution function. The goal of this project is to advance algorithms and theory for the underlying mathematical problem "the unlabeled distance geometry problem" with potential to impact indoor mapping and positioning, nanoscience, and genomics.

The unlabeled distance geometry problem lies at the intersection of signal processing, computer science, acoustics, and experimental nanoscience. In this project the investigator proposes to develop algorithms for the unlabeled distance geometry problem with provable guarantees, as well as practical recipes for using those algorithms in major applications. The team will place particular emphasis on the connections with the state-of-the-art developments in signal processing, especially phase retrieval, matrix completion, and semidefinite relaxations for non-convex problems, by developing computationally efficient relaxations that work with high probability over typical instances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Unassigned distance geometry is a mathematical model for problems ranging from molecular imaging to room acoustics. To understand this geometric puzzle imagine a shape built out of sticks of different lengths. The sticks are joined at their ends so that no end is left hanging and no stick is bent. They all fit snugly. Now imagine a violent giraffe trampling the structure. Can you put it back together?

If sticks are replaced by paths along which sound propagates in a room we get a model for room shape reconstruction from acoustic echoes. If they are replaced by bonds between atoms we get a model for powder diffraction, an experimental technique to determine the atomic 3D structure of materials. If they are replaced by gene sequences between cutting sites on a DNA strand we get a model for genome reconstruction. In all these problems the attribute "unassigned" signifies that we don't know which sticks go together.

A major issue with uDGP is that solving it, and thus advancing key applications, may require an excessive amount of calculations. Naive solutions that attempt to work for any possible stick structure may take a very long time, and much longer still when the sticks have imperfect lengths. There are also deep fundamental mysteries: with some collections of sticks it may be possible to build more than one structure. It is then important to understand when the reconstruction is unique and when it is not.

In this project we developed the first robust, computationally efficient method for solving the uDGP. By robust and efficient we mean that it works in reasonable time even when the distances are only measured coarsely, a feat that was absent previously. We also deepened our theoretical understanding by studying two simplifications of the full problem: the first simplification follows from formulating the uDGP as a peculiar system of quadratic equations. We  derived theoretical guarantees for solving such systems when equations are modeled as random. Randomness turns out to be easier to deal with than the deterministic equations in the real uDGP. The second simplification is to replace quadratic equations by linear but still keep the equations unlabeled, or shuffled (just as that giraffe shuffled the sticks). In this context we developed a sharp understanding of when unique reconstruction is possible. The last thing we did was to establish and explore the connections between the uDGP and the modern molecular imaging techniques like CryoEM. This continues to be an exciting line of inquiry.
